1.heading: Rug Beaters.
1.title: "May I Borrow Your Rug-Beater for a Few Minutes?"
1.author: Carl Anderson.
notes: Summary: Henry brings out what looks like a little brother.

2.heading: Rug Cleaner.
2.title: "Fuzz Let His Inner Puppy Out to Play"
2.author: Tom Wilson & Tom II.
notes: Summary: Ziggy has a bottle of rug cleaner; Fuzz is his dog.

3.heading: Rug Doctors.
3.title: Captain Rug-Doctor
3.author: created and written by Johnathan (Stinky) Yorick ; drawn by Colin Upton.
notes: Vancouver, B.C. : Colin Upton, between 1990 and 2010.

4.heading: Rug Shampooing.
4.title: "Now I Got Holes from Cigarette Butts, a Whole Acre to Vacuum, a Four-Wheel Drive Rug Shampoo Tractor with a Carpet Deodorizer Spreader"
4.author: MacNelly.
notes: Summary: Cosmo had the 'Marquis d'Sod Lawn Service' install astroturf, and there's no more weeds, seeds, fertilizing or watering.

5.heading: Rugby.
5.title: En Même Temps que la Jeunesse
5.author: Jean Harambat.

6.heading: Rugby.
6.title: "They Beat Wales So Viciously, I Half Expected to See Greenpeace Storm the Field"
6.author: Darby Conley.
notes: Summary: Rob got up in the middle of the night to watch the Springboks of South Africa play Wales.

7.heading: Rugby Coaches.
7.title: "Graham Lowe"
7.author: by Clayton Noone and Stefan Neville
7.appears_in: p. 182-185 in SPX 2002 : Biographical Comics Issue (Comic Book Legal Defense Fund, 2002).
notes: Lowe is a rugby coach from New Zealand.

10.heading: Ruger.
10.title: "In Darkness It Shall End!"
10.author: story, Doug Moench ; art, Vincente Alcazar
notes: "Peter stared horrified at Rowena's slashed throat. He had loved her, as did his rival, Ruger. Now she was dead! And only the grave had won. A logical assumption that nearly cost Peter his very life!"

11.heading: Rugg, Jim.
11.title: Afrodisiac
11.author: Jim Rugg and Brian Maruca.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): The crew behind Street Angel hits the ghetto with the Afrodisiac, in SuperColor! There's cats, gats, spats, and feathered hats, action as big as a Georgia ham and wool so fine it'll blow your mind! Lock up your daughters, come hell or high water, cause here comes the king of the concrete jungle.

12.heading: Rugg, Jim.
12.title: The Guild
12.author: script, Felicia Day ; art, Jim Rugg.
notes: "This volume reprints #1-3 of The Guild, as well as a short story from MySpace Dark Horse presents #27."
"This story takes place before the events of Season 1 of the web series The Guild created by Felicia Day."
Summary (from SkyRiver): Chronicles the on- and offline lives of a group of Internet role-playing gamers, the Knights of Good.

13.heading: Rugg, Jim.
13.title: Janes in Love
13.author: by Cecil Castellucci and Jim Rugg ; with lettering by Rob Clark, Jr
13.appears_in: and gray tones by Jasen Lex.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): As they continue their undercover art, the Janes contend with romantic woes, pursuit by a police officer, a lack of money for art supplies, and internal disagreements.

14.heading: Rugg, Jim.
14.title: MDHP : MySpace Dark Horse Presents : volume 4

contents.title: Conan and the mad king of Gaul

16.heading: Rugg, Jim.
16.title: One Model Nation
16.author: writer, C
16.appears_in: Allbritton Taylor ; historian, Donovan Leitch ; art (p. 16-134, cover), Jim Rugg ; art (p. 1-15, 135-136), Cary Porter ; color, Jon Fell ; lettering, Rowan Aldrin.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): In 1977, four young men were the voice of their generation. In 1978, they disappeared. This is the epic journey of the political art noise band, One Model Nation, the final dark days of the Baader-Meinoff Gang, and the band's mysterious disappearance only months later. Captured within these pages are the arts and politics of an era whose influence cannot be measured.

17.heading: Rugg, Jim.
17.title: The Plain Janes
17.author: by Cecil Castellucci and Jim Rugg ; with lettering by Jared K
notes: Summary (from OCLC): When Jane moves to the suburbs, she thinks her life is over, but she meets three friends who form a club P.L.A.I.N., but can art really save a group of misfits from high school?

18.heading: Rugg, Jim.
18.title: The Princess of Poverty
18.author: created and written by Jim Rugg and Brian Maruca ; drawn by Jim Rugg.
notes: "Collects issues #1-5 of the SLG Publishing series Street Angel."

"In the worst ghetto on Earth, a young, homeless orphan rules the streets with her fearsome kung fu and deadly skateboarding. Jesse "Street Angel" Sanchez fights ninja gangs, evil geologists, nepotism, ancient gods, homework, and hunger while perpetually seeking the Holy Grail of cardboard boxes."

19.heading: Rugg, Jim.
19.title: Rambo 3.5.
19.author: [No author]
notes: New wave genre, about George W. Bush.

20.heading: Rugg, Jim.

20.appears_in: Bone, guest artist, "Mix it up" ; Jim Rugg, guest artist, "Monsters of rock" ; Laura Allred, colorist ; Todd Klein, letterer.
notes: "Originally published in single magazine form in iZombie 19-28."

Summary (from SkyRiver): Following the zombie invasion of Eugene, Oregon, the newly-undead Gwen goes underground to elude the troops who have been sent to her town to kill zombies, one of whom is her boyfriend who just found out he has been dating a zombie.

35.author: by Harry Haenigsen.
notes: Summary: Trying to be helpful, Penny cleans a cupboard and burns newspapers her mother was saving. "Why don't you ask before you do things?" So she asks her father for something to do. "You should be able to find things to do without asking."

39.appears_in: 10 p. in Buffalo Bill Picture Stories, no. 1 (June/July 1949).
notes: Begins: "Young Cal had it tough from the time he was born, for the West in his time was a rugged place and Cal's life was made even tougher when his dad stood up to old man Grouty in a gun battle. His father went out in a blaze of guns. Was Cal destined to go out the same way?"

45.heading: Ruggiero, Lorenzo.
45.title: "All the Rage, part 2"
45.author: David Hine, writer ; Augustin Padilla, Andres Guinaldo, Lorenzo Ruggiero and Walden Wong, artwork
notes: Summary: Batman and Nightrunner save Leni Urbana, and Bruce gets to establish a Batman Incorporated franchise in France.
Story continued from Detective Comics Annual, no. 12 (Feb. 2011).
Data from Mike Nielsen and Gregory Fischer via Grand Comics Database.

46.heading: Ruggiero, Lorenzo.
46.title: Civil War
46.author: writer, Brian Reed ; pencils, Robert De La Torre & Mike Wieringo ; inks, Jon Sibal & Wade von Grawbadger, colors, Chris Sotomayor ; letters, Dave Sharpe ; Ms
46.appears_in: Marvel special: writer, Brian Reed ; pencils, Giuseppe Camuncoli ; inks, Lorenzo Ruggiero ; colors, Chris Sotomayor ; letters, Dave Sharpe.
notes: "Contains material originally published in magazine form as Ms. Marvel #6-10 and Ms. Marvel Special #1."

Summary (from SkyRiver): With the Super Hero Registration Act in effect, Carol Danvers (aka Ms. Marvel) joins forces with Simon "Wonder Man" Williams and Julia "Arachne" Carpenter to police and train heroes.

47.heading: Ruggiero, Lorenzo.
47.title: Dark Reign : Fantastic 4
47.author: writer, Jonathan Hickman ; collection editor, Cory Levine.
notes: "When the fallout from Reed's latest experiment forces Sue, Ben and Johnny to fight their way through time, the Fantastic trio find themselves staving off a super hero Hyborian-age civil war, defending the Holy Land in the Crusades, conquering the Wild West, beating back the Nazis and boldly going where no time-traveler has gone before! Meanwhile, back on Earth, it's Val and Franklin versus Norman Osborn and the agents of H.A.M.M.E.R.! Plus: alternate realities, Celestials, Eternals, Deviants, Doombots and the return of the Illuminati
and more important than all of that, find out the answer to the question: What is the Bridge?"
Artists are Sean Chen, Lorenzo Ruggiero, and Adi Granov.

Summary (from SkyRIver): The adventure of Chuckie and his sister Kim when they visit a petting zoo.

64.heading: Rugrats.
64.title: Junk, Sweet Junk
64.author: by Molly Wigand ; illustrated by Barry Goldberg.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): Tommy, Chuckie, and Angelica help Tommy's grandfather throw away the useless junk he has accumulated, but the children find new uses for most of it and Grandpa decides it has value after all. Based on the animated television show Rugrats.

65.heading: Rugrats.

notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Tommy, Chuckie, and Angelica help Tommy's grandfather throw away the useless junk he has accumulated, but the children find new uses for most of it and Grandpa decides it has value after all. Based on the animated television show Rugrats.

notes: Summary (from OCLC): After making a huge mess in the storeroom, Tommy, Chuckie, Phil, and Lil persuade Pete to let three stray cats live in his pizza parlor.

68.heading: Rugrats.
68.title: The Rugrats and the Zombies
68.author: by Sarah Willson ; illustrated by Barry Goldberg.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Tommy is afraid that his parents are turning into zombies when they start acting strangely following several sleepless nights.

69.heading: Rugrats.

70.heading: Rugrats.

70.author: by Sarah Willson ; illustrated by Peter Panas.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): When Tommy's mom decides sugar is bad for babies, his friends find ingenious ways to acquire sweets for him.

71.heading: Rugrats.
71.title: Tommy Catches a Cold
71.author: by Sarah Willson ; illustrated by Barry Goldberg.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): Tommy doesn't feel so good. He hears someone say he's caught a bug. Now he and his friends have to find the bug and let it go while his parents try all sorts of remedies.

72.heading: Rugrats.

72.author: adapted by Kitty Richards from the script by Mark Palmer ; based on the story by Laine Raichert, J

notes: Summary (from OCLC): When the Rugrats find out their new friend, the turkey, might become dinner, they try to help him escape
only their plans don't quite work! Includes a separate story of the first Thanksgiving celebration.

73.heading: Rugrats.

notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Lil and Phil can't get along until they are split up and miss each other, and Chuckie and Tommy must find a way to reunite them.

107.heading: Rugs.
107.title: "Brazil"
107.author: [No author]
107.series: Marco Polar Bear) p. 18-24 in Children's Digest, no. 29
notes: "Bobby is puzzled about something. Maybe he'll find the answer when the magic linoleum rug whishes him and Marco to new adventures in Brazil."

108.heading: Rugs.
108.title: "Daniel Boone's Interior Decorator"
108.author: by Leigh Rubin.
notes: Summary: Selecting a bear for a rug.

109.heading: Rugs.
109.title: "Getting Along Without a Maid"
109.author: King.
notes: Summary: Avery listens to his wife's reasoning that, since she's saving so much money by not having a maid, she should be able to afford an oriental rug, an overstuffed chair and some new table linen. He responds that not having a chauffeur or a valet should entitle him to a yacht.

110.heading: Rugs.
110.title: "Go Ahead! I'll Only Bleed All over Your New Rug"
110.author: Unger
110.appears_in: p. 35 in Battered Husbands (Redondo Beach, CA : H. Gregory Associates, 1991).
notes: Summary: She's approaching with a rolling pin.

111.heading: Rugs.
111.title: "He Fools Tige"
111.author: R
111.appears_in: F. Outcault. p. 14-15 in Buster Brown : a complete compilation, 1906 (Westport, Conn. : Hyperion, 1977)
notes: Summary: Buster puts a wolf skin rug on the floor, and Tige rips it to pieces.

112.heading: Rugs.
112.title: "His Trip to India"
112.author: [No author]
112.series: Marco Polar Bear) p. 101-107 in Children's Digest, no. 13
notes: Begins: "Hop on the magic rug as it whisks Marco and his errand boy Bobby off to new adventures."

113.heading: Rugs.
113.title: "I Didn't Hear a Thing, I Was Sound Asleep!"
113.author: Vern Greene
113.appears_in: reprinted (p. 62) in The National Cartoonists Society Album 1965 ed. (New York : NCS, 1965).
notes: Summary: Jiggs puts off fixing the rug, and Maggie takes a spill.

114.heading: Rugs.
114.title: "I Never Saw Anybody Beat a Rug with So Much Vim and Vigor"
114.author: Frank Willard
114.appears_in: p. 155 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: 54th in a sequence of 57 dailies reprinted here.
Summary: Mamie has pinned a picture of Major Bluepoint to the rug to motivate him.

115.heading: Rugs.
115.title: "I Wish We Had a Green Rug so My Grasshopper Would Feel More at Home"
115.author: Ketcham.
notes: Setting: Dennis is on the floor in the living room.

116.heading: Rugs.
116.title: "I Won't Let You Go to Work, so Forget It"
116.author: by Russ Westover.
notes: Summary: She wants a new rug and some furniture, and threatens to go to work and earn her own money.

117.heading: Rugs.
117.title: "I'll Put This Old Bear Rug on Top of Me!"
117.author: by Berndt.
notes: Summary: It's cold in the mountains at night.

118.heading: Rugs.
118.title: "Indoor Putting Green"
118.author: by Carl Anderson
118.appears_in: reproduced on p. 110 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Henry uses a bearskin rug for indoor golf.

119.heading: Rugs.
119.title: "Look At Me When I'm Speaking To You"
119.author: Virginia & George.
notes: Summary: He broke the stereo, a vase, and the TV, tore the drapes, tarred the rug, and his ball went through the picture window. Mom squirts him in the face.

120.heading: Rugs.
120.title: "The Magic Rugs"
120.author: [No author]
120.series: Johnny and Woof) 6 p. in Animal Crackers, no. 9
notes: Summary: Johnny and Woof (a dog) enter their artist's partly completed Arabian Nights story, with a magic lamp, a genie, a flying carpet, a cave of treasure and a princess to return to her Sultan father. A villain takes their magic carpet, but their artist reaches into the story and draws another one.

121.heading: Rugs.
121.title: "Mama, I Laid an Egg on the Dining-Room Rug"
121.author: Copi

122.heading: Rugs.
122.title: Market Day
122.author: James Sturm.
notes: Summary (from SkyRiver): Carting his lovingly handcrafted rugs to town, Mendleman discovers that the shop that carried his wares has been taken over by a new, bottom-line-oriented owner who stocks only cheaply made merchandise. With the disappearance of his patron, Mendleman's world is upended. His only recourse is to sell his rugs for a pittance to a grand new emporium. Although he must accept the insult for the survival of his young family, the blow drives the sensitive artist to the breaking point.

123.heading: Rugs.
123.title: "Offer to Give Them Plans for Building a Nuclear Weapon, Then Give Them Plans to Build Microwave Ovens Instead"
123.author: Scott Adams.
notes: Summary: The strategy should work on the Elbonians, because in the past it got them lots of rugs.

124.title: Rugs. "That Explains What Happened to the Rug"
124.author: Russell Myers.
notes: Summary: Broom-Hilda has to be stopped from using the vacuum cleaner on the lawn.

125.heading: Rugs.
125.title: "That's Right, Just Lift Your Feet Like You Do When I'm Sweeping the Rug"
125.author: by George Clark.
notes: Summary: She's using a push mower; he's in a lawn chair.

126.heading: Rugs.
126.title: "This Rug Must Need a Thicker Pad"
126.author: by Bill Watterson.
notes: Summary: Calvin shows how he can juggle a dozen eggs at once, and they all break when they fall.

127.heading: Rugs.
127.title: "A Throw Rug with Mange"
127.author: Armstrong.
notes: Summary: Marvin introduces his dog Bitsy.

128.heading: Rugs.
128.title: "We Can Do That After You Build a Loom"
128.author: Jerry Scott and Rick Kirkman.
notes: Summary: Zoe is doing a report on the invention of the rug, and her parents will help, a little.

129.heading: Rugs.
129.title: "What Jiggs and Maggie Did for George" p. 35 in Circulation, v. 4, no. 18
129.author: [No author]
notes: "Quaint characters aroused enthusiasm of Persian art connoisseur to such a pitch that he had made a beautiful rug as gift for creator of Bringing Up Father."
The new rug, six feet by five feet, is based on the cover of Circulation for Feb. 1922.

130.heading: Rugs.
130.title: "You Can Always Crawl Under the Rug"
130.author: [No author]
130.series: Our Boarding House with Major Hoople, Nov. 14, 1956
notes: Summary: Amos and the boarders complain about their blankets being thin, because the rest of them are at the cleaners. Martha says if they plan to freeze to death tonight they better pay their back rent now.

131.heading: Rugs.
131.title: "You Can Always Crawl Under the Rug"
131.author: [No author]
notes: Summary: Amos and the boarders have noticed a dearth of blankets and quilts, and Martha says the blankets are back from the cleaners tomorrow.

132.heading: Rugs.
132.title: "You Do Not Like My Pets, No?"
132.author: De Beck
132.series: Barney Google and Spark Plug, Oct. 31, 1930
132.appears_in: p. 161 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney suggests making rugs of the big cats, and Lena (now with stripes again) seems to understand.

135.author: Brian Ruh.

notes: Indonesian folk tales in comics format.

137.heading: Ruhiyat S.
137.title: Ramayana : Legenda Rama dan Sinta
137.author: Ruhiyat S.
notes: Comic book on Ramayana, the great epic of India.

138.heading: Ruhlman, Ryan.
138.title: "Cheating on Your Girlfriend and Ticking Off Your Roommate"
138.author: Ryan Ruhlman.
notes: Begins: "Grrr, I hope we're not too loud."
Clipped from the Daily Kent Stater.

139.heading: Ruhlman, Ryan.
139.title: "Damn These Student Loans"
139.author: Ryan Ruhlman.
notes: Summary: He finally has a real job, but there's still a problem.
Clipped from the Daily Kent Stater.

140.author: by Jan Sukus, illustrated by Ruth Ruhman and Gavy.
